content.question:
On-base percentage plus slugging <math alttext="(O P S)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OPS</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> is a statistic used in baseball to measure a team’s batting success. The number of runs scored and <math alttext="O P S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OPS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> baseball teams was used to conduct a linear regression analysis. The scatterplot and computer output for the regression analysis is shown.

Term
<math alttext="Coefficient" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Coef</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="S E Coefficient" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SE Coef</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="T value" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>T-Value</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="P value" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P-Value</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Constant
<math alttext="negative 838.40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mn>838.40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="77.99" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>77.99</mn></math>
<math alttext="negative 10.75" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mn>10.75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="less than 0.0001" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo><</mo><mn>0.0001</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="O P S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OPS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="2144.3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2144.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="107.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>107.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="20.01" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.01</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="less than 0.0001" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo><</mo><mn>0.0001</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="S equals 19.516" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>19.516</mn></math>

<math alttext="R squared, equals 93.47%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R-Sq</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>93.47</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="R squared, adjusted, equals 93.23%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R-Sq(adj)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>93.23</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of the statistic <math alttext="93.47%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>93.47</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the regression output?

choices.label: There is a strong, positive, linear relationship between number of runs scored and <math alttext="O P S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OPS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The typical deviation between observed and predicted number of runs scored is <math alttext="0.9347" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.9347</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

For each one-unit increase in <math alttext="O P S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OPS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the regression model predicts an increase of <math alttext="93.47" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>93.47</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> runs scored.

<math alttext="93.47%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>93.47</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>⁢</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of the observed number of runs scored are close to the regression line.

<math alttext="93.47%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>93.47</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of the variation in number of runs scored can be explained by the linear regression with <math alttext="O P S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OPS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="93.47%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>93.47</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of the variation in number of runs scored can be explained by the linear regression with <math alttext="O P S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OPS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Calculate summary statistics, relative positions of points within a distribution, correlation, and predicted response.
